text.p: These are the leading stories in the Turkish press on Thursday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- Foreign Minister Tansu Ciller threatens to pension off army commanders for intervening in politics. The military-dominated National Security Council (NSC) has asked the Islamist-led government to implement though measures to curb Islamist activism.
- The Istanbul stock exchange is last but one in a list of world stock exchanges ranked according to the number of transactions and returns in March.
- Minister of Defence Turhan Tayan says Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan and his Islamist party are responsible for the ongoing political tension.
- An Islamist preacher refused to conduct the funeral of a barman killed by gunmen after he was shown on a television channel with the word "God" tatood in Arabic on his body.
- The High Board of Privatisation approves the sell-off of seven ports.
- Mosques will only opened five times a day for prayer in the eastern province of Tunceli because an outlawed Islamist organisation and rebel Kurds have begun using them as bases.
- Private Is and Garanti banks have doubled their profits in the first quarter of 1997.
- Agriculture ministry says food cans are unhealthy in Turkey as they contain too much iron.
- Demand has risen for durable goods on the back of a public sector wage increases amid fears that prices will rise in the autumn.
- A conference held in Istanbul reveals that Turkey is not the only state that faces organised crime problems.
- Privatised plastic producer Petlas stops production for two days while it pays compensation to workers made redundant.
